chart.title: Children per woman vs. Natural population growth
chart.subtitle: [Natural population growth](#dod:population-growth-rate) measures the population increase determined by births and deaths, excluding changes due to migration.

Natural population growth rate - Sex: al.titleLong: Natural growth rate, total - UN WPP
Natural population growth rate - Sex: al.descriptionShort: Crude birth rate minus the crude death rate. Represents the portion of population growth (or decline) determined exclusively by births and deaths.
Natural population growth rate - Sex: al.citationShort: UN, World Population Prospects (2024) – processed by Our World in Data
Natural population growth rate - Sex: al.citationLong: UN, World Population Prospects (2024) – processed by Our World in Data. “Natural growth rate, total – UN WPP” [dataset]. United Nations, “World Population Prospects” [original data].

Fertility rate - Sex: all - Age: all - V.descriptionShort: The average number of live births a hypothetical cohort of women would have at the end of their reproductive period if they were subject during their whole lives to the fertility rates of a given period and if they were not subject to mortality.
descriptionKey: It is expressed as live births per woman. For age-specific fertility rates, it measures the number of births to women in a particular age group, divided by the number of women in that age group. The age groups used are: 15-19, 20-24, ..., 45-49. The data refer to annual civil calendar years from 1 January to 31 December.
Fertility rate - Sex: all - Age: all - V.citationShort: UN, World Population Prospects (2024) – processed by Our World in Data
Fertility rate - Sex: all - Age: all - V.citationLong: UN, World Population Prospects (2024) – processed by Our World in Data. “Fertility rate, total – UN WPP” [dataset]. United Nations, “World Population Prospects” [original data].

Population (historical).descriptionShort: Population by country, available from 10,000 BCE to 2023, based on data and estimates from different sources.
Population (historical).descriptionProcessing:
The population data is constructed by combining data from multiple sources:

- 10,000 BCE - 1799: Historical estimates by HYDE (v3.3).

- 1800 - 1949: Historical estimates by Gapminder (v7).

- 1950-2023: Population records by the UN World Population Prospects (2024 revision).
Population (historical).citationShort: HYDE (2023); Gapminder (2022); UN WPP (2024) – with major processing by Our World in Data
Population (historical).citationLong: HYDE (2023); Gapminder (2022); UN WPP (2024) – with major processing by Our World in Data. “Population (historical)” [dataset]. PBL Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency, “History Database of the Global Environment 3.3”; Gapminder, “Population v7”; United Nations, “World Population Prospects”; Gapminder, “Systema Globalis” [original data].

World regions according to OWID.citationShort: Our World in Data – processed by Our World in Data
World regions according to OWID.citationLong: Our World in Data – processed by Our World in Data. “World regions according to OWID” [dataset]. Our World in Data, “Regions” [original data].
